com.software.reuze

Class mp_ModelFiniteFullJoint

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.software.reuze.mp_ModelFiniteFullJoint
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    mp_i_Model, mp_i_ModelFinite
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    FullJointDistributionBurglaryAlarmModel, FullJointDistributionMeningitisStiffNeckModel, FullJointDistributionPairFairDiceModel, FullJointDistributionToothacheCavityCatchModel, FullJointDistributionToothacheCavityCatchWeatherModel

    public class mp_ModelFiniteFullJoint
extends Object
implements mp_i_ModelFinite
    An implementation of the FiniteProbabilityModel API using a full joint distribution as the underlying model.
    Author:
    Ciaran O'Reilly

      • isValid

        public boolean isValid()
        Specified by:
        isValid in interface mp_i_Model
        Returns:
        true, if 0 <= P(ω) <= 1 for every ω and ∑ω ∈ Ω P(ω) = 1 (Equation 13.1 pg. 484 AIMA3e), false otherwise.

      • prior

        public double prior(mp_i_Proposition... phi)
        Description copied from interface: mp_i_Model
        For any proposition φ, P(φ) = ∑ω ∈ φ P(ω). Refer to equation 13.2 page 485 of AIMA3e. Probabilities such as P(Total = 11) and P(doubles) are called unconditional or prior probabilities (and sometimes just "priors" for short); they refer to degrees of belief in propositions in the absence of any other information.
        Specified by:
        prior in interface mp_i_Model
        Parameters:
        phi - the propositional terms for which a probability value is to be returned.
        Returns:
        the probability of the proposition φ.

      • posterior

        public double posterior(mp_i_Proposition phi,
               mp_i_Proposition... evidence)
        Description copied from interface: mp_i_Model
        Unlike unconditional or prior probabilities, most of the time we have some information, usually called evidence, that has already been revealed. This is the conditional or posterior probability (or just "posterior" for short). Mathematically speaking, conditional probabilities are defined in terms of unconditional probabilities as follows, for any propositions a and b, we have:

        P(a | b) = P(a AND b)/P(b)

        which holds whenever P(b) > 0. Refer to equation 13.3 page 485 of AIMA3e. This can be rewritten in a different form called the product rule:

        P(a AND b) = P(a | b)P(b)

        and also as:

        P(a AND b) = P(b | a)P(a)

        whereby, equating the two right-hand sides and dividing by P(a) gives you Bayes' rule:

        P(b | a) = (P(a | b)P(b))/P(a) - i.e. (likelihood * prior)/evidence
        Specified by:
        posterior in interface mp_i_Model
        Parameters:
        phi - the proposition for which a probability value is to be returned.
        evidence - information we already have.
        Returns:
        the probability of the proposition φ given evidence.

      • getRepresentation

        public Set<mp_i_RandomVariable> getRepresentation()
        Specified by:
        getRepresentation in interface mp_i_Model
        Returns:
        a consistent ordered Set (e.g. LinkedHashSet) of the random variables describing the atomic variable/value pairs this probability model can take on. Refer to pg. 486 AIMA3e.

        Get a conditional distribution. Example:

        P(X | Y) gives the values of P(X = xi | Y = yj) for each possible i, j pair.

      • jointDistribution

        public mp_i_CategoricalDistributionIterator jointDistribution(mp_i_Proposition... propositions)
        Description copied from interface: mp_i_ModelFinite
        Get a distribution on multiple variables. Example, the product rule:

        P(X, Y) gives the values of P(X = xi | Y = yj)P(Y = yj) for each possible i, j pair.
        Specified by:
        jointDistribution in interface mp_i_ModelFinite
        Parameters:
        propositions - the propositions for which a joint probability distribution is to be returned.
        Returns:
        the joint distribution for P(X, Y, ...).
